sen.j: アメノタヂカラオ（アメノタヂカラヲ）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)。
sen.e: Ameno Tajikarao is a god that appears in the Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).
Ameno Tajikarao is a god that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).
Ameno Tajikarao is a god that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).

sen.j: 古事記では天手力男神、日本書紀では天手力雄神と表記される。
sen.e: "Kojiki "(Records of Ancient Matters) gives him "天手力男神" in Chinese character and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan). Gvies "天手力雄神.."
"Kojiki "(Records of Ancient Matters) is written "天手力男神" in Chinese characters and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan). Is written "天手力雄神."
Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) is written "天手力男神" in Chinese characters and Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) is written "天手力雄神."
sen.cmt: スペース削除原文に『』のない"を削除

sen.j: 神話での記述
sen.e: Mythological Description
Mythological Description
Mythological description
sen.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 岩戸隠れの際は岩戸の脇に控えており、アマテラスが岩戸から顔をのぞかせた時、アマテラスを引きずり出した（『日本書紀』の一書や『古語拾遺』では「引き開けた」）。
sen.e: While Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) was hiding herself in a cave (Iwadokakure), Tajikarao was staying at a side of the cave and, when Amaterasu peeked out, he pulled her out of the cave ("forced the rock to wide open" according to "Nihonshoki" and "Kogo-shui" (History of the Inbe clan)),
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: While Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) was hiding herself in a cave (Iwadokakure), Tajikarao was staying at the side of the cave and, when Amaterasu peeked out, he pulled her out of the cave ("forcing the rock wide open" according to "Nihonshoki" and "Kogo-shui" - History of the Inbe clan),

While Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) was hiding herself in a cave (Iwadokakure), Tajikarao was staying at the side of the cave and, when Amaterasu peeked out, he pulled her out of the cave ('forcing the rock wide open' according to "Nihonshoki" and "Kogo-shui" - History of the Inbe clan),

sen.j: こうして世界に明るさが戻った。
sen.e: As the result brightness returned in the world.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: As the result brightness returned in the world.
As the result brightness returned in the world.

sen.j: 天孫降臨の際、アマテラスが三種の神器にオモイカネ、タヂカラオ、天石別神を副えたとある。
sen.e: Amaterasu infused deities of Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent), Tajikarao, and Amannoiwatowake-no-kami into the three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family during its tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Amaterasu infused deities of Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent), Tajikarao, and Amannoiwatowake-no-kami into the three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family during its tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).

Amaterasu infused deities of Omoikane (the god of wisdom and talent), Tajikarao, and Amanoiwatowake no kami into the three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family during its tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).
sen.cmt: Amannoiwatowake-no-kami→Amanoiwatowake no kamiスペース削除

sen.j: その後伊勢国の佐那県に鎮座したとしている。
sen.e: Since then Ameno Tajikarao is believed to have been enshrined in Sana-no-agata, Ise Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Since then Ameno Tajikarao is believed to have been enshrined in Sana-no-agata, Ise Province.
Since then Ameno Tajikarao is believed to have been enshrined in Sana no agata, Ise Province.

sen.j: 解説
sen.e: Explanation
Explanation
Explanation

sen.j: 名前は「手の力の強い男神」の意であり、腕力・筋力の象徴である。
sen.e: Ameno Tajikarao, whose name means "a male god having arm strengths," represents a physical strength or muscular strength.
Ameno Tajikarao, whose name means "a male god having strong arms," representing physical strength or muscular strength.
Ameno Tajikarao, whose name means 'a male god having strong arms,' representing physical strength or muscular strength.

sen.j: 信仰
sen.e: Worship
Worship
Worship

sen.j: 力の神、スポーツの神として信仰されており、戸隠神社（長野県長野市）、佐那神社（三重県多気郡）、白井神社（兵庫県尼崎市）、雄山神社（富山県中新川郡立山町）、手力雄神社 (岐阜市)（岐阜県岐阜市）、手力雄神社 (各務原市)（岐阜県各務原市）、戸明神社（福岡県北九州市）、天手長男神社（長崎県壱岐市）、神命愛心会那須別宮（栃木県那須郡）などに祀られている。
sen.e: Worshipped as a god of power or sports, Ameno Tajikarao is enshrined, for example, in Togakushi-jinja Shrine (Nagano city, Nagano prefecture), Sana-jinja Shrine (Taki-gun, Mie Prefecture), Shirai-jinja Shrine (Amazasaki city, Hyogo prefecture), Oyama-jinja Shrine (Tateyama-machi, Nakaniigawa-gun, Toyama Prefecture), Tejikarao-jinja Shrine (Gifu City, Gifu prefecture), Tejikarao-jinja Shrine (Kagamihara City, Gifu Prefecture), Toake-jinja Shrine (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture), Amanotanagao-jinja Shrine (Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture), and Nasubekku Shrine of Shinmeiaishin-kai (Nasu District, Tochigi Prefecture).
sen.cmt: (岐阜市)（岐阜県岐阜市）、(各務原市)（岐阜県各務原市）は、（岐阜県岐阜市）および（岐阜県各務原市）のみ訳し出ししています。
sen.e: Worshipped as a god of power or sports, Ameno Tajikarao is enshrined, for example, in Togakushi-jinja Shrine (Nagano city, Nagano prefecture), Sana-jinja Shrine (Taki-gun, Mie Prefecture), Shirai-jinja Shrine (Amazasaki city, Hyogo prefecture), Oyama-jinja Shrine (Tateyama-machi, Nakaniigawa-gun, Toyama Prefecture), Tejikarao-jinja Shrine (Gifu City, Gifu prefecture), Tejikarao-jinja Shrine (Kagamihara City, Gifu Prefecture), Toake-jinja Shrine (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture), Amanotanagao-jinja Shrine (Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture), and Nasubekku Shrine of Shinmeiaishin-kai (Nasu District, Tochigi Prefecture).

Worshipped as a god of power or sports, Ameno Tajikarao is enshrined, for example, in Togakushi-jinja Shrine (Nagano City, Nagano Prefecture), Sana-jinja Shrine (Taki-gun, Mie Prefecture), Shirai-jinja Shrine (Amagasaki City, Hyogo Prefecture), Oyama-jinja Shrine (Tateyama-machi, Nakaniigawa-gun, Toyama Prefecture), Tejikarao-jinja Shrine (Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture), Tejikarao-jinja Shrine (Kagamihara City, Gifu Prefecture), Toake-jinja Shrine (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture), Amanotanagao-jinja Shrine (Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture), and Nasubekku Shrine of Shinmeiaishin-kai (Nasu-gun, Tochigi Prefecture).

sen.j: 戸隠神社については、タヂカラオが放り投げた岩戸の扉が信濃国戸隠山に落ちたという伝説がある。
sen.e: A legend connected to Togakushi-jinja Shrine goes that the rock of the cave thrown by Tajikarao fell on Mt. Togakushi, Shiga Province.
A legend connected to Togakushi-jinja Shrine goes that the rock of the cave thrown by Tajikarao fell on Mt. Togakushi, Shiga Province.
A legend connected to Togakushi-jinja Shrine goes that the rock of the cave thrown by Tajikarao fell on Mt. Togakushi, Shiga Province.

sen.j: 雄山神社に祀られるタヂカラオは立山修験の神である。
sen.e: Tajikarao enshrined in Oyama-jinja Shrine is a god of Shugen.in the Tateyama Mountain.
Tajikarao enshrined in Oyama-jinja Shrine is a god of Shugen.on Mt.Tateyama.
Tajikarao enshrined in Oyama-jinja Shrine is a god of Shugen on Mt.Tateyama.

sen.j: 立山山頂にある峰本社の本尊は阿弥陀如来と不動明王であるとされ、本地垂迹によってそれぞれイザナミとタヂカラオであるとされた。
sen.e: Located at the summit of the Tateyama Mountain, the two honzon (principal images of Buddha) of Mine-honsha Shrine are believed to be Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata) and Fudo Myoo (Acala, one of the Five Wisdom Kings), which Honji-suijaku (theory of original reality and manifested traces) defines as Izanami and Tajikarao Honji-suijaku (theory of original reality and manifested traces), respectively.

Located at the summit of Mt.Tateyama, the two honzon (principal images of Buddha) of Mine-honsha Shrine are believed to be Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata) and Fudo Myoo (Acala, one of the Five Wisdom Kings), which Honji-suijaku (theory of original reality and manifested traces) defines as Izanami and Tajikarao Honji-suijaku (theory of original reality and manifested traces), respectively.

Located at the summit of Mt. Tateyama, the two honzon (principal images of Buddha) of Mine-honsha Shrine are believed to be Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata) and Fudo Myoo (Acala, one of the Five Wisdom Kings), which Honji-suijaku (theory of original reality and manifested traces) defines as Izanami and Tajikarao Honji-suijaku (theory of original reality and manifested traces), respectively.

sen.j: 元々雄山神社・戸隠神社とも、山岳信仰を起源とする神社であり、この神が山岳信仰と関係のある神であることを示している。
sen.e: Oyama-jinja Shrine and Togakushi-jinja Shrine have their origins in mountain worship, which shows that Tajikarao is related to mountain worship.
Oyama-jinja Shrine and Togakushi-jinja Shrine have their origins in mountain worship, which shows that Tajikarao is related to mountain worship.
Oyama-jinja Shrine and Togakushi-jinja Shrine have their origins in mountain worship, which shows that Tajikarao is related to mountain worship.

sen.j: 日本には、祖霊は山に帰り、田の神は山から降りてくるなど、山は異界であるという観念があった。
sen.e: There was a belief in Japan that mountains were in a different world; for example, sorei (ancestral spirit, collective of ancestral spirits which have lost their individualities, ancestor deified as a kami, spirit of a kami) returns to mountains and tanokami (deity of rice fields and harvests) comes down a mountain.

There was a belief in Japan that mountains were a different world; for example, sorei (ancestral spirit, collective ancestral spirits which have lost their individualities, ancestor deified as a kami, spirit of a kami) return to the mountains and tanokami (deity of rice fields and harvests) comes down from a mountain.

There was a belief in Japan that mountains were a different world; for example, sorei (ancestral spirit, collective ancestral spirits which have lost their individualities, ancestor deified as a kami, spirit of a kami) return to the mountains and tanokami (deity of rice fields and harvests) comes down from a mountain.

sen.j: これが仏教の地獄の思想と結びついて平安時代以降の山岳信仰となる。
sen.e: This belief was connected to an Buddhism idea of Hell and developed into a mountain worship in and after the Heian period.
This belief was connected to an Buddhism idea of Hell and developed into a mountain worship in and after the Heian period.
This belief was connected to a Buddhist concept of Hell and developed into a mountain worship in and after the Heian period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 異界である山との境界から、タヂカラオが引き開けた天岩戸が連想される。
sen.e: The Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven) that Ameno Tajikarao opened wide can be associated with the border of a different world in a mountain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven) that Ameno Tajikarao opened wide can be associated with the border of a different world existing in a mountain.
The Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven) that Ameno Tajikarao opened wide can be associated with the border of a different world existing in a mountain.

sen.j: このため、タヂカラオが山と結びつけられたものと考えられる。
sen.e: This is because Tajikarao was associated with with mountains.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: This is because Tajikarao was associated with with mountains.
This is because Tajikarao was associated with mountains.

sen.j: 怪力を持つというイメージのあるタヂカラオは、昔から人々に人気があり、各地にタヂカラオが登場する神楽が伝わる。
sen.e: Tajikarao thought of as a god having phenomenal physical strength has been popular among people since early times and thus kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines) in which he appears have been handed down all over Japan.

Tajikarao thought of as a god having phenomenal physical strength has been popular among people since early times and thus kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines) in which he appears have been handed down all over Japan.
The popular image of the deity Tajikarao is one of a god with phenomenal physical strength and he appears in many kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines) performed around Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。
